bibl.title: Greek Tyranny and Roman Emperors during the Severan Period: A Case Study of P. Col. 123 and SEG XVII 759.
bibl.note: Incorporates the text of the presentation given at the Tyranny and Response panel at the Association of Ancient Historians meeting held May 6, 2011 in Mercyhurst College, Erie, Pennsylvania. A case study comparing two documents from the Severan period, a papyrus from Egypt [P. Col. VI, 123 (Apokrimata)] and an inscription from Syria [S.E.G. XVII, 759], illustrates the expectations placed on the Emperors and how they dealt with them in practice. - Avec résumé en anglais.

bibl.title: Bulletin of the Institute of Classical Studies [London]

bibl.seg: Kaius Tuori, Greek Tyranny and Roman Emperors during the Severan Period: A Case Study of P. Col. 123 and SEG XVII 759.

Incorporates the text of the presentation given at the Tyranny and Response panel at the Association of Ancient Historians meeting held May 6, 2011 in Mercyhurst College, Erie, Pennsylvania. A case study comparing two documents from the Severan period, a papyrus from Egypt [P. Col. VI, 123 (Apokrimata)] and an inscription from Syria [S.E.G. XVII, 759], illustrates the expectations placed on the Emperors and how they dealt with them in practice. - Avec résumé en anglais.
